articles.headline: Trump’s Intervention in SEALs Case Tests Pentagon’s Tolerance
articles.snippet: Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher’s case pits a Pentagon hierarchy committed to enforcing longstanding rules of combat against a commander in chief with no military experience but a finely honed sense of grievance against authority.
articles.abstract: Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher’s case pits a Pentagon hierarchy committed to enforcing longstanding rules of combat against a commander in chief with no military experience but a finely honed sense of grievance against authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was limp and dusty from an explosion, conscious but barely. A far cry from the fierce, masked Islamic State fighters who once seized vast swaths of Iraq and Syria, the captive was a scraggly teenager in a tank top with limbs so thin that his watch slid easily off his wrist.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps, Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Plunge in 3 Hong Kong Stocks Offers a Cautionary Tale
articles.snippet: The sudden drops raise fresh questions about corporate governance and regulatory oversight in a crossroads for global finance.
articles.abstract: The sudden drops raise fresh questions about corporate governance and regulatory oversight in a crossroads for global finance.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Even by the standards of Hong Kong, where the ups and downs of the stock market rival events at the horse track as a spectator sport, three recent flameouts have been spectacular.

articles.headline: How a Divided Left Is Losing the Battle on Abortion
articles.snippet: Miscalculations, and an unexpected victory by President Trump, have put abortion access at its most vulnerable point in decades, and the left on the defensive. Now it is trying to recover.
articles.abstract: Miscalculations, and an unexpected victory by President Trump, have put abortion access at its most vulnerable point in decades, and the left on the defensive. Now it is trying to recover.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The pin was small, and rusted on the back. Sharon Wood had packed it away in 1973 as a relic of a battle fought and won: the image of a black coat hanger, slashed out by a red line.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: In Prince Andrew Scandal, Prince Charles Emerges as Monarch-in-Waiting
articles.snippet: After a public-relations debacle stirred questions about the role of Queen Elizabeth II, the Prince of Wales is asserting a newfound authority in British royal affairs.
articles.abstract: After a public-relations debacle stirred questions about the role of Queen Elizabeth II, the Prince of Wales is asserting a newfound authority in British royal affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Queen Elizabeth II welcomes President Trump and other world leaders to Buckingham Palace on Tuesday to mark the 70th anniversary of NATO, it will be another testament to her extraordinary longevity: She acceded to the throne only three years after the alliance was formed.

articles.headline: Trump’s Other Personal Lawyer: Close to the Right, but Far From Giuliani
articles.snippet: Jay Sekulow is a trusted, telegenic presidential adviser more experienced in religious liberty cases than impeachment battles.
articles.abstract: Jay Sekulow is a trusted, telegenic presidential adviser more experienced in religious liberty cases than impeachment battles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jay Sekulow is a real lawyer, and he plays one on TV.

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade Deal Steals a Page From Democrats’ Playbook
articles.snippet: The president has made a trade agreement that caters to his opposition — and that’s why it stands a chance of passing Congress.
articles.abstract: The president has made a trade agreement that caters to his opposition — and that’s why it stands a chance of passing Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats return to Washington on Monday facing a difficult choice: Should they hand President Trump a victory in the midst of a heated impeachment battle or walk away from one of the most progressive trade pacts ever negotiated by either party?
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: With Brutal Crackdown, Iran Is Convulsed by Worst Unrest in 40 Years
articles.snippet: What started as a protest over a surprise increase in gasoline prices turned into widespread demonstrations met with a systematic repression that left at least 180 people dead.
articles.abstract: What started as a protest over a surprise increase in gasoline prices turned into widespread demonstrations met with a systematic repression that left at least 180 people dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran is experiencing its deadliest political unrest since the Islamic Revolution 40 years ago, with at least 180 people killed — and possibly hundreds more — as angry protests have been smothered in a government crackdown of unbridled force.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: ‘Turn Off the Sunshine’: Why Shade Is a Mark of Privilege in Los Angeles
articles.snippet: Shade in Los Angeles sits at the intersection of two crises: climate change and income inequality. City officials are rushing to deploy cover to hundreds of bus stops and plant 90,000 trees.
articles.abstract: Shade in Los Angeles sits at the intersection of two crises: climate change and income inequality. City officials are rushing to deploy cover to hundreds of bus stops and plant 90,000 trees.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There is no end to the glittering emblems of privilege in this city. Teslas clog the freeways. Affluent families scramble for coveted spots in fancy kindergartens. And up in the hills of Bel-Air, where a sprawling estate just hit the market for a record $225 million, lush trees line the streets, providing welcome relief from punishing heat.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Bethany Mollenkof

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Embraces Western Sports to Rehabilitate Global Image
articles.snippet: Critics accuse the kingdom of “sportswashing” as international entertainment businesses shrug off human rights concerns.
articles.abstract: Critics accuse the kingdom of “sportswashing” as international entertainment businesses shrug off human rights concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — On Halloween, as two female WWE wrestlers battled inside a roaring King Fahd International Stadium, Najla Ibrahim stood with a hand on her heart and another in the air, capturing the moment with her smartphone. For years, the nurse from Riyadh followed wrestling from afar and yearned for the day when women would take the ring in her country.

articles.headline: Trump Says U.S. Will Impose Metal Tariffs on Brazil and Argentina
articles.snippet: The president, in a move that would shatter previous agreements with those countries, accused them of weakening their currencies and hurting American farmers.
articles.abstract: The president, in a move that would shatter previous agreements with those countries, accused them of weakening their currencies and hurting American farmers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that he would impose tariffs on steel and aluminum from Brazil and Argentina, a move that would shatter previous agreements with those countries and widen a global trade war that the president had appeared ready to scale back.

articles.headline: Activist’s Case Hints at What Changes and What Stays the Same in Cuba
articles.snippet: José Daniel Ferrer’s arrest reflects the lengths to which the Díaz-Canel government will go against dissidents.
articles.abstract: José Daniel Ferrer’s arrest reflects the lengths to which the Díaz-Canel government will go against dissidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The activist José Daniel Ferrer García made his desperate plea by hand.
